questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of blisters on her forearm that appeared 3 days ago. She also reports pain in her left cheek when eating and pain during sexual intercourse for the past week. She has not been sick for the past 6 months. She has started hiking in the woods on the weekends with her son a couple of months ago but has been careful to avoid poison ivy. She has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. She recently started taking captopril and stopped taking meloxicam 2 weeks ago. She has a family history of pernicious anemia and Graves disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple, flaccid blisters over the volar surface of the forearm and ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa. The epidermis on the forearm separates when the skin is lightly stroked. The total body surface area involvement of the blisters is estimated to be 10%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus typically affects patients 30–60 years of age and may manifest with lesions on the skin as well as the mucous membranes of the oral cavity and/or genitalia. Antihypertensive drugs have been known to trigger lichen planus-like eruptions. However, lichen planus usually manifests as firm, shiny, reddish-purple, polygonal papules that are intensely pruritic, and the enanthem would typically appear as white streaks forming a lace-like network (Wickham striae) or fixed white plaques. Blister formation is not usually seen in patients with lichen planus.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left wrist

Multiple erythematous papules, which are partially confluent are visible on the flexor side of the wrist. The papules are polygonal in shape and appear to be slightly elevated.

This finding is characteristic of cutaneous lichen planus. as polygonal, pink, slightly elevated, sharply demarcated, and partially confluent and partially grouped.

B) INCORRECT:

Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), which can be induced by therapy with oxicam NSAIDs such as meloxicam, would result in blisters of the skin and mucous membranes as well as a positive Nikolsky sign. However, TEN usually occurs within 8 weeks of initiating therapy with the drug, whereas this patient had presumably been on meloxicam for a longer period. Moreover, patients with TEN typically have widespread involvement of the skin surface (> 30% of the body surface area) and systemic features such as fever, tachycardia, and hypotension.
Image Description:

The trunk and arm show generalized, widespread, extensive necrosis with purple and red erythema, as well as yellow-white exudation. Spots of hemorrhagic, subepidermal tissue can also be seen.

These characteristic findings are distinctive for TEN, a severe form of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).

C) INCORRECT:

Behcet disease can cause painful oral and genital ulcers as well as cutaneous lesions. However, the cutaneous manifestations of Behcet disease typically appear as papulopustular lesions or lesions resembling erythema nodosum; blisters are not characteristic. Moreover, Behcet disease typically occurs between 20–40 years, and clinical features of uveitis such as eye pain and redness, decreased vision, and/or hypopyon are often present.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS) can manifest with painful blisters and a positive Nikolsky sign. However, SSSS typically occurs in children below the age of 6 years and blisters would be accompanied by erythema of the surrounding skin and features of systemic toxicity such as fever and/or malaise. Also, mucosal involvement does not occur in SSSS, and the onset of blisters would be preceded by a staphylococcal infection (e.g., impetigo, staphylococcal diarrhea).

E) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis can cause blistering of the skin. However, dermatitis herpetiformis typically affects the extensor surfaces of elbows, knees, and buttocks, and patients usually present with intense pruritus. Mucosal involvement does not typically occur.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

F) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid can be caused by captopril and would manifest with cutaneous blisters. However, the blisters are typically tense and occur symmetrically, with a predilection for intertriginous areas, while Nikolsky sign is typically negative. Moreover, bullous pemphigoid usually manifests with a prodromal phase, which is characterized by pruritus and papules/urticarial lesions/skin excoriations. Lastly, mucous membranes (especially those of the genitalia) are typically spared in patients with bullous pemphigoid.
Image Description:

Erythematous skin with a solitary tense blister (unknown localization) is visible in the center of the image.

This appearance is typical of bullous pemphigoid.

G) CORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) is an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins such as desmoglein 3 and desmoglein 1. Thiol-containing drugs (e.g., captopril, penicillamine) and phenol-containing drugs (e.g., cephalosporins, rifampicin, phenobarbital, aspirin) can induce the formation of these autoantibodies. Since desmosomal adhesion proteins enable keratinocyte adherence, damage to these proteins causes intraepidermal bullae formation and a positive Nikolsky sign. The lesions typically occur first on mucous membranes and can become confluent or erode to form painful ulcers. PV is treated with high-dose systemic corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive medications (e.g., azathioprine, IVIG, rituximab). Severe PV can be fatal, as it can lead to bacterial superinfection, fluid loss, and/or electrolyte imbalance.

See “Overview of blistering diseases” table.
Image Description:

Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is confirmed via biopsy, which would show acantholysis and deposition of IgG in the intercellular spaces of the epidermis.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of a rash across his trunk and extremities. For the past 3 months, he has had persistent pruritus in these areas. He started hiking in the woods with his grandson last week to try to lose weight. His grandson, who often spends the weekends with him, recently had impetigo. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis of his thumbs. Five months ago, he was treated for a gout attack of his left hallux. Current medications include captopril, hydrochlorothiazide, simvastatin, allopurinol, and ibuprofen. Vital signs are within normal limits. There are diffuse vesicles and tense blisters involving the chest, flexures of the arms, and shoulders. Rubbing the skin on his chest does not produce blisters. Oral examination shows no abnormalities. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following findings?

choices.text: Growth of Gram-positive bacteria on blood culture
Antibodies to varicella zoster virus on serologic testing
Antibodies to desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3 on direct immunofluorescence studies
Antibodies to tissue transglutaminase on serologic testing
Growth of HSV-1 on viral culture from blister
Linear deposits of IgG and C3 along the basement membrane on direct immunofluorescence studies
Subepidermal separation with full-thickness epidermal necrosis on skin biopsy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Growth of gram-positive bacteria on blood culture is a diagnostic finding of staphylococcal bacteremia, which can be a focus of infection in patients with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS). While this patient's grandson has a history of impetigo, which puts the patient at increased risk for staphylococcal infection, SSSS typically manifests with a positive Nikolsky sign and primarily affects infants and young children. In addition, the prodromal phase of SSSS includes fever, malaise, and skin tenderness, whereas this patient only had persistent pruritus.
Image Description:

There is diffuse erythema of all visible skin. Large ruptured blisters are visible on the left lower leg, and a large flaccid unruptured blister can be seen on the left buttock.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibodies to varicella-zoster virus (VZV) on serologic testing are a diagnostic finding in VZV infection, which can also manifest as vesicular or bullous lesions (shingles). However, VZV infection typically manifests with fever, headache, and severely painful blisters with a burning or stabbing quality. The cutaneous lesions typically have a dermatomal distribution.
Image Description:

A widespread erythematous papular rash is visible over the left inguinal region. Several individual and confluent vesicles can be seen in a T12-L1 dermatomal distribution. Additional lesions are visible beyond this distribution.

This is the characteristic appearance of shingles (herpes zoster infection).

C) INCORRECT:

Antibodies to desmoglein 1 and desmoglein 3 are a diagnostic finding in pemphigus vulgaris, which also manifests with blisters. However, nearly all patients develop mucosal involvement, with lesions most commonly developing in the oral cavity, which is also typically the first area of involvement. Furthermore, unlike in BP, the blisters are flaccid and the Nikolsky sign is positive.
Image Description:

Flaccid bullae and gray-white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

D) INCORRECT:

Tissue transglutaminase antibodies are a common finding in patients with celiac disease. There is an association between celiac disease and dermatitis herpetiformis, an autoimmune blistering disease that typically manifests in adults 20–50 years with grouped, tense, pruritic vesicles that develop on the extensor surfaces of the extremities. However, in contrast to this patient, there is no prodromal stage. Additionally, this patient does not have a history of gastrointestinal disease.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

E) INCORRECT:

Growth of HSV-1 on viral culture taken from a fresh vesicle confirms a diagnosis of HSV infection, which can also manifest as a vesicular eruption on the chest, as in eczema herpeticum. However, lesions are typically umbilicated vesicles that progress to punched-out erosions, not tense bullae. In addition, eczema herpeticum typically follows other skin conditions, such as atopic dermatitis.
Image Description:

Multiple monomorphic, umbilicated, vesicular papules and punched-out erosions with hemorrhagic crusts are visible on the back of a young patient with a history of atopic eczema.

These findings are consistent with eczema herpeticum, a dermatological emergency requiring urgent evaluation and immediate antiviral therapy. Lesions located near the eyes require referral to ophthalmology due to the risk for corneal involvement.

F) CORRECT:

Direct immunofluorescence studies are the gold standard for diagnosing BP and typically show linear deposits of IgG and C3 along the basement membrane. These IgG autoantibodies are directed against the bullous pemphigoid antigen on hemidesmosomes. Samples for skin biopsy should come from perilesional skin (e.g., erythematous areas adjacent to a blister). BP is the most common autoimmune blistering disease and typically manifests in older adults with numerous tense bullae. These appear after a prodromal phase characterized by pruritic eczematous, papular, or urticarial lesions. The bullae are typically 1–3 cm in size and commonly involve the trunk, extremity flexures, and inguinal folds. As in this patient, the oral mucosa is often unaffected. The bullae eventually rupture, leaving moist erosions that crust over and resolve without scarring. Some drugs can induce BP, including penicillamine, furosemide, and captopril.
Image Description:

Tense blisters, erosions, and crusts on erythematous skin are visible on the knee.

These findings are consistent with bullous pemphigoid.

G) INCORRECT:

Spongiotic dermatitis is a histopathological feature of allergic contact dermatitis, which can manifest as vesicles and bullae after exposure to poison oak or poison ivy. Although this patient may have been exposed on one of his recent hikes, allergic contact dermatitis does not explain his months of prodromal symptoms.
Image Description:

Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right arm

An erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.

This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

H) INCORRECT:

Subepidermal separation with full-thickness epidermal necrosis on skin biopsy is a diagnostic finding in Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), which also manifests with tense, subepidermal bullae. SJS is an important differential diagnosis in a patient taking allopurinol, which is one of the principal triggers of SJS. However, over 90% of patients with SJS have mucosal involvement and, typically, appear ill. In addition, the prodromal phase of SJS includes fever, malaise, myalgia, and arthralgia, whereas this patient only had prodromal pruritus. Lastly, the Nikolsky sign is often positive, unlike in this patient.
Image Description:

There is desquamation of the tongue and pustules are visible on the lips.

Mucosal involvement occurs in > 90% of SJS cases. This can help differentiate it from staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), where mucusal membranes are typically not involved.
questions.hint: This older patient presents with tense bullae and prodromal pruritus with no mucosal involvement and a negative Nikolsky sign, all of which are consistent with bullous pemphigoid (BP).

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of pruritic blister formation. Physical examination shows multiple 1–3 cm bullae on the palms, soles, lower legs, and inguinal folds. Gentle rubbing of the skin does not result in sloughing of the epidermis. Immunofluorescence studies of a perilesional skin biopsy specimen are most likely to show deposition of antibodies in which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Direct immunofluorescence in bullous pemphigoid reveals linear deposition of IgG and C3 at the dermo-epidermal junction. The bullae are formed due to an immune reaction caused by autoantibodies directed against bullous pemphigoid antigen 1 and bullous pemphigoid antigen 2 (components of the hemidesmosome). Microscopic examination of a blistering lesion usually reveals the presence of eosinophils with the separation of tissue layers subepidermally causing tense bullae.

Bullous pemphigoid is a benign disease that usually responds well to treatment with high-dose topical steroids.
Image Description:

A: Microscopy (100x magnification) with immunofluorescence using IgG and C3 autoantibodies showing deposition along the basement membrane of a skin tissue sample.

B: Microscopy (200x magnification) with indirect immunofluorescence using IgG and C3 autoantibodies showing deposition along the epidermal junction of a skin tissue sample.

B) INCORRECT:

Deposition of antibodies between epidermal keratinocytes is seen in pemphigus vulgaris, characterized by acantholysis that results in the formation of intraepidermal blisters and bullae. Acantholysis is induced by IgG antibodies directed against desmoglein 3 and desmoglein 1, which usually mediate keratinocyte adherence. Blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are flaccid and nonpruritic rather than tense and pruritic as seen here. Moreover, lesions typically first present on the oral mucosa and the Nikolsky sign is positive.
Image Description:

Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

C) INCORRECT:

No staining on direct immunofluorescence is observed in Stevens Johnson syndrome as the pathogenesis is thought to be a T-cell mediated type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which does not involve antibody antigen interaction. Although bullae are present in this disease, other skin features include extensive, full-thickness epidermal necrosis and sloughing (resembling large superficial burns) and mucosal involvement along with a positive Nikolsky sign.
Image Description:

Right arm of an infant in whom toxic epidermal necrolysis was likely triggered by smallpox vaccination

D) INCORRECT:

Granular deposits of IgA in the dermal papillae are observed in dermatitis herpetiformis with antibodies directed against epidermal transglutaminase. Although dermatitis herpetiformis presents with pruritic blisters, they are usually in grouped (herpetiform) arrangement and the most commonly involved sites include elbows, dorsal forearms, knees, scalp, back, and buttocks. Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

E) INCORRECT:

Perivascular immunoglobulin deposition is seen in porphyria cutanea tarda. Although it presents with bullae and blisters, they are a manifestation of chronic photosensitivity. Moreover, other skin features including increased scarring, hypertrichosis, and hyperpigmentation affecting sun-exposed areas of the body, are absent here. Lastly, porphyria cutanea tarda mainly occurs in older men with chronic alcoholism and hepatic cirrhosis.
Image Description:

A fluid-filled blister is visible on the index finger. Deep ulcers and superficial erosions can be seen on the back of the left hand.

These features are consistent with porphyria cutanea tarda.
questions.hint: The patient presents with large, pruritic bullae on the palms, soles, lower legs, and inguinal folds, sparing the mouth. Nikolsky sign is negative. These clinical features are typical of bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disease, most common in older adults.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a severely pruritic skin rash. Physical examination shows a symmetrical rash over the knees and elbows with tense, grouped vesicles, and several excoriation marks. Microabscesses in the papillary dermis are seen on light microscopy. Immunofluorescence shows deposits of immunoglobulin A at the tips of dermal papillae. This patient's skin findings are most likely associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mites, their eggs, and/or fecal pellets can be found on dermoscopy in patients with scabies. Though scabies can manifest with intensely pruritic, scattered vesicles, the pruritus is typically worse at night. Additionally, scabies usually affects the creases of the body (e.g., interdigital web spaces, the antecubital and popliteal fossae, groin), not the elbows and shoulders. Lastly, this patient does not have dark red burrows (2–10 mm in length) in the dermis, which are tunnels created by the female mite.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous papules (partially excoriated) are visible in the interdigital folds and on the dorsal aspect of the hand and fingers.

B) INCORRECT:

White dermographism is associated with atopic dermatitis, which typically manifests with a poorly demarcated, lichenified rash in flexural creases (e.g., antecubital and popliteal fossae) rather than grouped vesicles on extensor surfaces. White dermographism is not seen in DH.
Image Description:

The skin of the arm is visibly white in the area where the patient scratched their skin.

The phenomenon known as white dermatographism is a result of capillary vasoconstriction and is associated with atopic dermatitis.

C) CORRECT:

Gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity causes celiac disease, a condition strongly associated with DH. The majority of patients with DH have gastrointestinal disease related to gluten sensitivity on histopathologic examination, despite lacking gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., bloating, diarrhea, abdominal pain). In addition to lifelong avoidance of gluten-containing foods, the first-line treatment of DH is dapsone.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

D) INCORRECT:

Multinucleated giant cells found on scrapings of an ulcer base (i.e., a positive Tzanck smear) indicate herpes simplex virus infections (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus infections (VZV). HSV infections cause grouped, vesicular lesions, which are typically painful (not pruritic) and usually manifest around the mouth (HSV-1) or genital (HSV-2) area. VZV infections cause chickenpox and shingles, which also manifest as vesicular lesions. However, chickenpox causes a more widespread rash, and shingles typically manifests in a dermatomal distribution. Systemic signs (e.g., fever, malaise) are also commonly present.
Image Description:

Numerous grouped vesicles are visible on dermatome T1/T2, exclusively on the left side. Some vesicles appear hemorrhagic.

This appearance together with its typical distribution pattern along dermatomes is typical of herpes zoster, which is caused by the reactivation of the varicella zoster virus.

E) INCORRECT:

Nail pitting is a key feature of psoriasis, which can also manifest with a pruritic rash on the extensor surfaces (e.g., elbows). However, this rash typically consists of clearly demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales (not grouped vesicles). Characteristic microscopic findings in psoriasis include neutrophilic microabscesses (Munro microabscesses) in the stratum corneum, not microabscesses and IgA deposits in the papillary dermis.
Image Description:

Multiple round, sharply demarcated, scaly, erythematous plaques are visible on the arms and trunk.

This appearance is typical of guttate psoriasis, a subtype of psoriasis.

F) INCORRECT:

A positive Nikolsky sign is seen in pemphigus vulgaris, a condition that also manifests with skin blisters. However, these blisters are typically flaccid and usually first appear on the buccal mucosa. In addition, the lesions are characteristically painful (not pruritic). Histopathologic examination shows IgG deposits in the epidermis accompanied by acantholysis. In DH, the oral mucosa is not typically involved and Nikolsky sign is negative.
Image Description:

Multiple ruptured blisters with surrounding erythema are visible. A single intact blister can be seen in the center of the image.

This finding is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris, but histopathology is required to confirm the diagnosis.
questions.hint: This patient's skin findings (symmetrical, pruritic, grouped, subepidermal vesicles on extensor surfaces) are manifestations of dermatitis herpetiformis (DH). The severe pruritus can lead to excoriations, as seen here. Papillary deposits of IgA confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of blisters on her forearms and pain during sexual intercourse. Her only medications are metformin and glyburide. Examination reveals multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearms and ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa. The epidermis on the forearm separates when the skin is lightly stroked. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

SSSS can present with painful blisters and a positive Nikolsky sign, as in this patient. However, the disease typically occurs in children below the age of 6 years and blisters would be accompanied by erythema of the surrounding skin and features of systemic toxicity such as fever and/or malaise. Also, mucosal involvement does not occur in the condition, and the onset of blisters would be preceded by a staphylococcal infection (e.g., impetigo, staphylococcal diarrhea).

B) CORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins, including desmoglein 3 and desmoglein 1. Certain medications, such as captopril, glyburide, thiol-containing drugs (e.g., penicillamine), and phenol-containing drugs (e.g., cephalosporins, rifampicin, phenobarbital, aspirin), can induce the formation of these autoantibodies. Since desmosomal adhesion proteins enable keratinocyte adherence, damage to these proteins causes intraepidermal bullae formation and a positive Nikolsky sign. The lesions typically occur first on mucous membranes and can become confluent or erode to form painful ulcers.

Pemphigus vulgaris is treated with high-dose systemic corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive medications (e.g., azathioprine, IVIG, rituximab). Severe pemphigus vulgaris can be fatal, as it can lead to bacterial superinfection, fluid loss, and/or electrolyte imbalance.
Image Description:

Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

C) INCORRECT:

Behcet disease can cause painful oral and genital ulcers as well as cutaneous lesions, as in this patient. However, the cutaneous manifestations of Behcet disease typically appear as papulopustular lesions or lesions resembling erythema nodosum; blisters are not seen. Moreover, Behcet disease typically occurs between 20–40 years, and clinical features of uveitis such as decreased vision, eye pain, red eye, and/or hypopyon would be present.

D) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus can present with lesions on the skin as well as the mucous membranes of the oral cavity and/or genitalia, as in this patient. However, lichen planus usually manifests as firm, shiny, reddish-purple, polygonal papules that are intensely pruritic, and the enanthem would typically appear as white streaks forming a lace-like network (Wickham striae) or fixed white plaques. Blister formation is not usually seen in patients with lichen planus.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left wrist

Multiple erythematous papules, which are partially confluent are visible on the flexor side of the wrist. The papules are polygonal in shape and appear to be slightly elevated.

This finding is characteristic of cutaneous lichen planus. as polygonal, pink, slightly elevated, sharply demarcated, and partially confluent and partially grouped.

E) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis can cause blistering of the skin, as in this patient. However, dermatitis herpetiformis typically affects the extensor surfaces of elbows, knees, and buttocks, and patients usually complain of intense pruritus. Moreover, mucosal involvement does not typically occur.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

F) INCORRECT:

Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) would result in blisters of the skin and mucous membranes as well as a positive Nikolsky sign, as in this patient. However, patients with TEN typically have widespread involvement of the skin surface and systemic features such as fever, tachycardia, and hypotension.
Image Description:

Right arm of an infant in whom toxic epidermal necrolysis was likely triggered by smallpox vaccination

G) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid presents with cutaneous blisters, as in this patient. However, the blisters are typically tense and occur symmetrically, with a predilection for intertriginous areas. Moreover, a prodromal phase that is characterized by pruritus and papules/urticarial lesions/skin excoriations would occur, the Nikolsky sign would be negative, and mucous membranes (especially those of the genitalia) would typically be spared.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is confirmed via biopsy, which would show acantholysis and deposition of IgG in the intercellular spaces of the epidermis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 12-day history of a rash over her arms and back. She says the rash is intensely itchy but not painful. Last year, she had a transient episode of a similar rash, but it did not last as long as this episode. She also reports episodic crampy abdominal pain that she has had for several years. Medical history is remarkable for hypertension and bipolar disorder. Her medications are lisinopril, lamotrigine, and a daily multivitamin. She walks one mile daily for exercise. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 135/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a symmetrical rash over the elbows, forearms, lower back, and buttocks. Examination of the oropharynx shows no abnormalities. A photograph of this patient's rash is shown. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's skin condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discontinuation of lamotrigine is appropriate in Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), which is triggered by drugs in approx. 80% of cases. Although SJS also manifests with an erythematous rash, the rash is typically painful and includes the formation of bullae with a positive Nikolsky sign and full-thickness epidermal necrosis and sloughing. Furthermore, in contrast to what is seen here, mucosal membranes are almost always involved in SJS. This patient most likely has DH, which is not triggered by lamotrigine.
Image Description:

Area below the popliteal fossa of the right knee (image mirrored and rotated left by 90°) of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

B) CORRECT:

DH is typically seen in individuals between 15 and 40 years of age and is a manifestation of gluten sensitivity. Although most patients with DH have celiac disease, only a minority have clinically significant gastrointestinal symptoms. Treatment consists of strict adherence to a gluten-free diet and oral dapsone. After symptomatic control, dapsone may be slowly tapered and stopped but a lifelong gluten-free diet should be maintained, especially in patients with concomitant celiac disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Avoidance of sun exposure is appropriate in photodermatoses, such as polymorphous light eruption, which can manifest with recurring, pruritic erythematous papules and vesicles. However, in photodermatoses, only sun-exposed areas are involved. This patient most likely has DH, which is not triggered by sun exposure.
Image Description:

Left hand of a patient with pruritus after exposure to sunlight

Numerous small papules are visible on the dorsum of the hand.

In a patient with a history of direct exposure to sunlight, these features are consistent with polymorphous light eruption.

D) INCORRECT:

Discontinuation of lisinopril is appropriate in drug-induced pemphigus vulgaris, which manifests with erythematous blisters. However, the blisters are typically painful and usually first appear on the oral mucosa. In addition, pruritus is characteristically absent. This patient most likely has DH, which is not triggered by lisinopril.
Image Description:

Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

E) INCORRECT:

Frequent moisturization is appropriate in atopic dermatitis (AD), which also manifests with a pruritic rash. However, AD typically manifests with poorly demarcated, dry, lichenified lesions in flexural creases (antecubital and popliteal fossae) rather than on the elbows and lower back. Moreover, grouped vesicles are not typical. Frequent moisturization has no definite role in the treatment of DH, which this patient most likely has.
Image Description:

Papulovesicular erythema and hyperpigmentation are visible on the popliteal fossae of both legs

F) INCORRECT:

Washing of clothing and bedding is appropriate in scabies infestation, which also manifests with pruritic, erythematous papules and vesicles. However, patients classically have intense pruritus that is worst at night. Moreover, scabies affects the creases of the body (e.g., interdigital web spaces, cubital/popliteal fossa, groin) rather than the elbows and lower back. Finally, dark red burrows (2–10 mm in length) in the dermis, which represent tunnels created by the female mite, are typically seen.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous, partly excoriated papules and burrows are visible on the back of the hand, the fingers, and the intertriginous area.
questions.hint: This patient's recurrent, symmetrical, and intensely pruritic rash with clusters of excoriated, erythematous papules and vesicles without mucosal involvement is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis (DH). Lesions most commonly affect extensor surfaces (e.g., elbows, forearms, back, buttocks).

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman reports a progressively pruritic eruption on her abdomen and buttocks. She has a history of hypertension and was recently treated with furosemide for lower-leg swelling.
Physical examination reveals erythematous, urticarial plaques admixed with tense bullae and hemorrhagic crusts on the buttocks, abdomen, and legs (figure). There are no mucosal lesions. The Nikolsky sign is negative.
Laboratory testing is notable for peripheral eosinophilia.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Localized bullae may be seen in cellulitis, but this patient’s diffuse and bilateral presentation without evidence of systemic toxicity is not consistent with cellulitis. Although rare infectious organisms such as Francisella tularensis and Vibrio vulnificus can cause localized, hemorrhagic bullae, these lesions are not pruritic or urticarial, and they do not have the same widespread distribution across the body as would be seen in an ambulatory patient with bullous pemphigoid.

B) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris is also an autoimmune blistering disease that can be drug induced. However, it is typically characterized by erosions and flaccid bullae with a positive Nikolsky sign; it often has mucosal involvement; and patients do not usually present with tense bullae.

C) INCORRECT:

The early phases of bullous pemphigoid can mimic urticaria, and occasionally a biopsy is required to identify the true diagnosis. Classic urticaria, even in exaggerated forms, does not result in tense bullae.

D) CORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid is a chronic subepidermal, autoimmune blistering disease that most commonly affects older adults. It is characterized by urticarial plaques with tense bullae that, when ruptured, result in hemorrhagic crusts and ulcerations. A negative Nikolsky sign (whereby lateral pressure next to a bullae does not create a blister) indicates a subepidermal process. Peripheral eosinophilia may occur in up to 50% of patients. Bullous pemphigoid can be idiopathic or drug induced, with identical clinical and histologic features. Several medications have been associated with drug-induced bullous pemphigoid, including furosemide, antibiotics, and most recently, checkpoint inhibitors.

Key learning point: The presence of pruritic, tense bullae and urticarial plaques in an older patient is most consistent with bullous pemphigoid, which may be drug induced.

E) INCORRECT:

Edema bullae are typically distributed in areas of significant and prolonged edema, which is not the clinical context in this case. In addition, edema bullae would not be accompanied by the intense pruritus, focal or discrete tense bullae, and hemorrhagic crusts reported in this patient.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman reports a 3-week history of progressive oral pain. She says she has difficulty eating and that her gums bleed when she brushes her teeth. She also developed painful blisters on her trunk and extremities during the same time frame. She is otherwise healthy, takes no medications, and has no additional symptoms.
Examination reveals flaccid bullae on the trunk and extremities, as well as erosions along the mandibular gingiva and on the posterolateral aspect of her tongue (figure).
While awaiting an appointment with the dermatologist, the patient has appropriate laboratory studies conducted and is found to have elevated titers of anti-desmoglein-1 and anti-desmoglein-3 autoantibodies.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a severe cutaneous adverse reaction, most often to a medication, leading to cutaneous and mucosal disease. This condition is not associated with anti-desmoglein-3 antibodies and is unlikely in this patient, who has not taken any new medications.

B) CORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disease related to autoantibodies against desmoglein-1 and desmoglein-3, components of desmosomes that mediate skin keratinocyte adhesion and epidermal integrity. These antibodies disrupt the normal function of desmogleins in the skin and the mouth, leading to acantholysis that clinically manifests as vesicles, bullae, and erosions on the skin and mucosal surfaces such as the oral cavity. Lateral traction on a blister can propagate the blister forward by extending the intraepidermal split, a finding called the Nikolsky sign.

Patients with severe pemphigus vulgaris characteristically present with painful oral erosions that may progress to difficulty eating and weight loss. Extensive cutaneous involvement may compromise skin-barrier function and predispose patients to significant insensible fluid losses, electrolyte abnormalities, and infections. Treatment involves systemic glucocorticoids and use of a glucocorticoid-sparing agent such as mycophenolate mofetil, intravenous immunoglobulin, or rituximab.

Key learning point: Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disease that causes oral and cutaneous erosions.

C) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid is a distinct autoimmune blistering disease related to autoantibodies against components of the hemidesmosome apparatus that anchors the basal keratinocytes to the basement membrane (bullous pemphigoid antigens 1 and 2). The cutaneous blisters are characteristically tense rather than flaccid, and affected patients usually describe intense pruritus.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpetic gingivostomatitis can cause oral erosions and blisters, but it is self-limited in immunocompetent patients. Affected patients usually also have constitutional symptoms such as malaise and fever.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythema multiforme is an inflammatory reaction to an infection or medication. It manifests with macules and papules that have concentric color changes and resemble a target symbol. Although this condition may blister or affect mucosal surfaces such as the mouth, it is not associated with anti-desmoglein-3 autoantibodies.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the office because of a 2-day history of blisters on her forearms and pain during sexual intercourse. Her only medications are metformin and glyburide. Examination reveals multiple, flaccid blisters on the volar surface of the forearms and ulcers on the buccal, gingival, and vulvar mucosa. The epidermis on the forearm separates when the skin is lightly stroked. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

SSSS can present with painful blisters and a positive Nikolsky sign, as in this patient. However, the disease typically occurs in children below the age of 6 years and blisters would be accompanied by erythema of the surrounding skin and features of systemic toxicity such as fever and/or malaise. Also, mucosal involvement does not occur in the condition, and the onset of blisters would be preceded by a staphylococcal infection (e.g., impetigo, staphylococcal diarrhea).

B) CORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins, including desmoglein 3 and desmoglein 1. Certain medications, such as captopril, glyburide, thiol-containing drugs (e.g., penicillamine), and phenol-containing drugs (e.g., cephalosporins, rifampicin, phenobarbital, aspirin), can induce the formation of these autoantibodies. Since desmosomal adhesion proteins enable keratinocyte adherence, damage to these proteins causes intraepidermal bullae formation and a positive Nikolsky sign. The lesions typically occur first on mucous membranes and can become confluent or erode to form painful ulcers.

Pemphigus vulgaris is treated with high-dose systemic corticosteroids and other immunosuppressive medications (e.g., azathioprine, IVIG, rituximab). Severe pemphigus vulgaris can be fatal, as it can lead to bacterial superinfection, fluid loss, and/or electrolyte imbalance.
Image Description:

Flaccid lesions with white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

C) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis can cause blistering of the skin, as in this patient. However, dermatitis herpetiformis typically affects the extensor surfaces of elbows, knees, and buttocks, and patients usually complain of intense pruritus. Moreover, mucosal involvement does not typically occur.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

D) INCORRECT:

Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) would result in blisters of the skin and mucous membranes as well as a positive Nikolsky sign, as in this patient. However, patients with TEN typically have widespread involvement of the skin surface and systemic features such as fever, tachycardia, and hypotension.
Image Description:

Right arm of an infant in whom toxic epidermal necrolysis was likely triggered by smallpox vaccination

E) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid presents with cutaneous blisters, as in this patient. However, the blisters are typically tense and occur symmetrically, with a predilection for intertriginous areas. Moreover, a prodromal phase that is characterized by pruritus and papules/urticarial lesions/skin excoriations would occur, the Nikolsky sign would be negative, and mucous membranes (especially those of the genitalia) would typically be spared.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is confirmed via biopsy, which would show acantholysis and deposition of IgG in the intercellular spaces of the epidermis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of a severely pruritic skin rash. On examination, there is a symmetrical rash over the knees and elbows with tense, grouped vesicles and several excoriation marks. Light microscopy reveals microabscesses in the papillary dermis. Immunofluorescence shows deposits of immunoglobulin A at the tips of dermal papillae. Which one of the following is most likely associated with these skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multinucleated giant cells found on scrapings of an ulcer base (i.e., a positive Tzanck smear) indicate herpes simplex virus infections (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus infections (VZV). HSV infections cause grouped, vesicular lesions, which are typically painful (not pruritic) and usually manifest around the mouth (HSV-1) or genital (HSV-2) area. VZV infections cause chickenpox and shingles, which also manifest as vesicular lesions. However, chickenpox causes a more widespread rash, and shingles typically manifests in a dermatomal distribution. Systemic signs (e.g., fever, malaise) are also commonly present.

B) INCORRECT:

Nail pitting is a key feature of psoriasis, which can also manifest with a pruritic rash on the extensor surfaces (e.g., elbows). However, this rash typically consists of clearly demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales (not grouped vesicles). Characteristic microscopic findings in psoriasis include neutrophilic microabscesses (Munro microabscesses) in the stratum corneum, not microabscesses and IgA deposits in the papillary dermis.

C) CORRECT:

Gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity causes celiac disease, a condition strongly associated with DH. The majority of patients with DH have gastrointestinal disease related to gluten sensitivity on histopathologic examination, despite lacking gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., bloating, diarrhea, abdominal pain). In addition to lifelong avoidance of gluten-containing foods, the first-line treatment of DH is dapsone.

Key learning point: Dermatitis herpetiformis presents with pruritic, grouped vesicles on extensor surfaces and is strongly associated with gluten sensitivity due to gliadin-dependent hypersensitivity, often seen in celiac disease.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.

D) INCORRECT:

A positive Nikolsky sign is seen in pemphigus vulgaris, a condition that also manifests with skin blisters. However, these blisters are typically flaccid and usually first appear on the buccal mucosa. In addition, the lesions are characteristically painful (not pruritic). Histopathologic examination shows IgG deposits in the epidermis accompanied by acantholysis. In DH, the oral mucosa is not typically involved and Nikolsky sign is negative.

E) INCORRECT:

White dermographism is associated with atopic dermatitis, which typically manifests with a poorly demarcated, lichenified rash in flexural creases (e.g., antecubital and popliteal fossae) rather than grouped vesicles on extensor surfaces. White dermographism is not seen in DH.
questions.hint: This patient's skin findings (symmetrical, pruritic, grouped, subepidermal vesicles on extensor surfaces) are manifestations of dermatitis herpetiformis (DH). The severe pruritus can lead to excoriations, as seen here. Papillary deposits of IgA confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 6-week history of painful oral lesions that began as small blisters but now appear as shallow erosions on her buccal mucosa. She reports difficulty eating and a 10-pound (4.5-kg) weight loss. Over the past 2 weeks, she has developed similar flaccid, thin-walled blisters on her trunk and neck that rupture easily, leaving painful crusted erosions. The lesions are not pruritic. On examination, gentle lateral pressure on normal-appearing skin adjacent to a lesion causes the epidermis to separate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid typically manifests with large, tense, pruritic vesicles and a negative Nikolsky sign. It most commonly affects adults > 70 years of age, and only 10–30% of patients have oral involvement.

B) CORRECT:

Correct. This patient's clinical presentation is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris, which typically begins with painful mucosal lesions (especially the oral mucosa) that precede cutaneous involvement by weeks to months. Flaccid, easily ruptured blisters that coalesce into painful erosions and a positive Nikolsky sign (lateral pressure causing epidermal separation) are characteristic features of this autoimmune blistering disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis manifests with intensely pruritic, tense, grouped subepidermal vesicles in a bilateral, symmetrical distribution, commonly over the elbows, knees, buttocks, and shoulders. Mucosal involvement is rare, and the Nikolsky sign is negative, which is not consistent with this patient's presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Contact dermatitis manifests with distinct borders corresponding to areas of allergen exposure and is typically pruritic. Mucosal involvement and a positive Nikolsky sign are not features of contact dermatitis. Additionally, there is no known exposure to potential allergens.

E) INCORRECT:

Bullous impetigo manifests with large, thin-walled bullae that rupture to form thin, serous crusts, but it has a negative Nikolsky sign and typically does not involve the oral mucosa. It most commonly occurs in children and does not progress from oral to cutaneous involvement.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the ED with a 3-week history of painful oral ulcers that began on her buccal mucosa and have made eating difficult, resulting in 8-pound weight loss. Over the past week, she developed flaccid blisters on her chest and back that rupture easily, leaving painful, crusted erosions. Physical examination reveals multiple shallow, painful oral erosions and several ruptured bullae with crusted bases on her trunk. Gentle lateral pressure on intact skin adjacent to a lesion causes the epidermis to separate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid typically affects patients over 70 years with large, tense, pruritic blisters. Oral involvement occurs in only 10-30% of patients, and the Nikolsky sign is characteristically negative, unlike this presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis presents with intensely pruritic, grouped vesicles primarily on extensor surfaces like elbows, knees, and buttocks. Oral involvement is rare.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Pemphigus vulgaris often begins with painful mucosal erosions that typically precede cutaneous involvement by weeks to months. The flaccid blisters rupture easily, forming painful crusted erosions. The Nikolsky sign is often positive during active disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus typically causes clustered vesicles that become shallow ulcers but does not produce the widespread flaccid blistering pattern with positive Nikolsky sign seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome involves mucosal erosions but typically presents with target lesions, widespread erythema, and systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter with painful bullae on his chest, back, and oral mucosa. He reports progressive worsening over 2 weeks and poor oral intake over the last 4 days. Vital signs are BP, 92/58; P, 110; R, 24; T, 37.8°C (100°F). On physical examination, mucous membranes are dry and there are multiple oral erosions. There are extensive flaccid bullae on the chest and back, and multiple bullae have ruptured, leaving raw erosions. Nikolsky sign is positive. There is no erythema or swelling surrounding the lesions. Laboratory results show sodium 130 mEq/L, potassium 4.7 mEq/L, creatinine 1.9 mg/dL, and WBC 10,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Steroids are the definitive treatment for pemphigus vulgaris. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable and has electrolyte abnormalities, and has to be stabilized first.

B) INCORRECT:

While superinfection of lesions is a complication of pemphigus vulgaris, this patient currently has no swelling or erythema surrounding the lesions and no systemic signs of infection (normal temperature, WBC only mildly elevated). Another step is required to stabilize the patient.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient is in hypovolemic shock and has hyponatremia and acute kidney injury, likely due to fluid loss through widespread ruptured bullae. Aggressive IV fluid resuscitation, electrolyte replacement, pain management, wound care to prevent secondary infection, and dermatology consultation to guide further management are required.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical debridement is indicated for necrotizing soft tissue infections, which can manifest with bullae. However, other signs of infection such as local erythema and swelling or fever and more significant WBC elevation would be expected. This patient has positive Nikolsky sign, which makes pemphigus vulgaris the more likely cause of his symptoms, and he requires a different treatment approach.

E) INCORRECT:

IVIG is used for severe or refractory pemphigus vulgaris. While IVIG may eventually be appropriate, this hemodynamically unstable patient requires a different step in management first.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man presents with a 3-week history of a severely pruritic rash. The rash began as red, raised patches on his abdomen and thighs, which have now progressed to form large blisters. He denies any new medications or recent illnesses. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F). Physical examination shows numerous large, tense bullae filled with clear fluid on an erythematous and urticarial base on his lower abdomen and inner thighs. The oral mucosa is clear. Gentle lateral pressure on the skin adjacent to a bulla does not result in epidermal sloughing. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although dermatitis herpetiformis is intensely pruritic, it is characterized by small, grouped vesicles (herpetiform) on extensor surfaces such as the elbows, knees, and buttocks, not large bullae on the abdomen and thighs. It is also strongly associated with celiac disease and typically presents in younger adults.

B) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disease, but it is caused by autoantibodies against desmogleins, leading to an intraepidermal split. This results in flaccid, easily ruptured bullae and a positive Nikolsky sign. Furthermore, painful oral mucosal erosions are a common and often initial feature, which are absent in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Bullous impetigo is a superficial bacterial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It typically presents with flaccid, not tense, bullae that rupture easily, leaving a thin collarette of scale. This condition is far more common in children, and the widespread, intensely pruritic nature seen in this older adult would be atypical.

D) INCORRECT:

Erythema multiforme major can present with bullae, but its hallmark is the presence of targetoid lesions. Additionally, the 'major' form is defined by significant mucosal involvement (oral, ocular, and genital), which this patient does not have. The rash typically begins on the extremities and spreads centrally.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disease that typically affects older adults. It is caused by IgG autoantibodies targeting hemidesmosomal proteins at the dermal-epidermal junction. This leads to a subepidermal split, creating a strong roof for the blisters, which explains why they are large and tense. The inflammatory response causes intense pruritus and an urticarial or erythematous base. The epidermis remains intact over the dermis, resulting in a negative Nikolsky sign. The absence of oral mucosal lesions is also characteristic. Diagnosis is confirmed with a skin biopsy showing a subepidermal blister and direct immunofluorescence showing linear IgG and complement component 3 deposits along the basement membrane.
questions.hint: In an older adult, intense pruritus, tense bullae, and a negative Nikolsky sign are highly characteristic of an autoimmune blistering disease affecting the basement membrane zone.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painful blisters under the arms that appeared 3 days ago. She has also had a 2-month history of intermittent, painful lesions in the mouth. Examination of the mouth shows several erosions on the buccal mucosa and lips. Examination of the trunk shows multiple flaccid blisters with a diameter of approximately 2 cm in both armpits. Skin biopsy specimens obtained from the area around the lesions show detachment of keratinocytes within the stratum spinosum. This patient's condition is most likely caused by autoantibodies directed against components of which of the following cell junctions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gap junctions are cell-to-cell junctions that link the cytoplasms of two adjacent cells. These cell junctions are found in most tissues, including skin, neurons, and cardiac muscle. Mutations in gap junctions can result in a wide range of manifestations due to abnormal connections between cells; however, there are no known conditions associated with autoantibody formation against gap junctions. In addition, mutations in gap junctions are not known to cause mucocutaneous blisters.

B) INCORRECT:

Tight junctions are epithelial junctions that form a barrier against paracellular leakage. Autoantibodies against tight junctions can compromise the barrier function of various tissues (e.g., skin, intestine) and have been implicated in atopic dermatitis and autoimmune gastrointestinal disorders. However, autoantibodies against tight junctions are not known to cause mucocutaneous blisters.

C) INCORRECT:

IgG autoantibodies to hemidesmosomes are seen in patients with bullous pemphigoid. This condition manifests with a prodromal stage of pruritic urticaria followed by the formation of subepidermal blisters, which typically develop on the palms, soles, lower legs, groin, and axillae. Unlike the blisters seen in pemphigus vulgaris, these blisters are tense. In addition, bullous pemphigoid is rarely associated with mucosal involvement.

D) INCORRECT:

Adherens junctions are belt-like, cell-to-cell connections between epithelial cells that are formed via linkage with the actin cytoskeleton. There are no medical conditions that are known to be caused by autoantibodies directed against adherens junctions.

E) CORRECT:

IgG autoantibodies to desmosomal components (desmoglein 1 and 3) can be seen in patients with pemphigus vulgaris. The formation of autoantibodies to these structural proteins results in loss of cell-cell adhesion, leading to mucocutaneous blister formation, as seen in this patient. The oral cavity is the most common site of mucosal involvement; painful mouth blisters typically erode quickly, leaving erosions. Cutaneous involvement manifests with flaccid blisters with a positive Nikolsky sign. Histopathologic examination shows acantholysis, intradermal vesicle formation, and deposition of IgG.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a skin biopsy sample (H&E stain) from a blister

Epidermis (purple region on the superior aspect; E):
– Suprabasal cleft (yellow overlays): A split above the basal layer of the epidermis that has led to blister formation is visible.
An unruptured blister can be seen on the right; a ruptured blister is visible on the left.
– Acantholysis: detached free-floating cells within the blisters
– Tombstone effect (green outlines): Keratinocytes of the basal layer are arranged in a single row of dark blue cells lining the inferior aspect of the blisters.
– An inflammatory infiltrate is visible through all layers of the epidermis.

Dermis (pink region on the inferior aspect; D): intact with minimal inflammatory infiltrate

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris, which is caused by a loss of desmosomes and thus cell adherence.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is associated with a positive Nikolsky sign.
